column2: What is your organization's current operating model?
column3: Decentralized operations - If you limit the scope of operations to one workload or a small collection of workloads, complexity can be controlled. As such, decentralized operations are the least complex of the common operating models.

column2: What is your organization's current operating model?
column3: Centralized operations - Central operations tend to be the norm for technology environments that consist primarily of stable-state workloads. Examples of a stable-state of operations include things like commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) applications or well-established custom applications that have a slow-release cadence.
column4: Centralized operations - Central operations tend to be the norm for technology environments that consist primarily of stable-state workloads. Examples of a stable-state of operations include things like commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) applications or well-established custom applications that have a slow-release cadence.

column2: What is your organization's current operating model?
column3: Enterprise operations - Enterprise operations are the suggested target state for all cloud operations. Enterprise operations balance the need for control and innovation by democratizing decisions and responsibilities.

column2: What is your organization's current operating model?
column3: Distributed operations - The existing operating model might be too engrained for the entire organization to shift to a new operating model. For others, global operations and various compliance requirements might prevent specific business units from making a change. A distributing operations approach might be required for those companies. This approach is by far the most complex approach. It requires an integration of one or more of the previously mentioned operating models.

column2: Which option best describes your current Azure identity services infrastructure?
column3: No Microsoft Entra tenant.

column2: Which option best describes your current Azure identity services infrastructure?
column3: One Microsoft Entra tenant. No identity synchronization from on-premises Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), but AD DS are in use on-premises. Users have two accounts: one for on-premises, and one for Microsoft Entra ID federated resources (like Microsoft 365).

column2: Which option best describes your current Azure identity services infrastructure?
column3: Multiple Microsoft Entra tenants, with one tenant for each environment (prod, test, dev).

column2: Which option best describes your current Azure identity services infrastructure?
column3: Multiple Microsoft Entra tenants due to acquisitions of or mergers between multiple organizations.

column2: Which option best describes your current Azure identity services infrastructure?
column3: One Microsoft Entra tenant with identity synchronization from on-premises Active Directory Domain Services via Microsoft Entra Connect. Users have a single account across on-premises and Microsoft Entra ID federated resources (such as Microsoft 365).
column4: One Microsoft Entra tenant with identity synchronization from on-premises Active Directory Domain Services via Microsoft Entra Connect. Users have a single account across on-premises and Microsoft Entra ID federated resources (such as Microsoft 365).

column2: Which services/features do you use to authenticate and authorize access to Azure resources?
column3: Microsoft Entra Conditional Access policies

column2: Which services/features do you use to authenticate and authorize access to Azure resources?
column3: Username & Password + MFA (Microsoft Entra multifactor authentication or 3rd party MFA) + Microsoft Entra Conditional Access policies
column4: Username & Password + MFA (Microsoft Entra multifactor authentication or 3rd party MFA) + Microsoft Entra Conditional Access policies

column3: Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM)
column4: Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM)

column3: Microsoft Entra Security Defaults

column3: IT Administrators & VIP users

column2: Have you implemented and configured emergency access accounts (aka "break glass accounts") for Microsoft Entra ID?
column3: No
column4: No

column2: Have you implemented and configured emergency access accounts (aka "break glass accounts") for Microsoft Entra ID?
column3: Yes, but none are excluded from MFA or Conditional Access policies or have a Microsoft Entra PIM permanent role assignment

column2: Have you implemented and configured emergency access accounts (aka "break glass accounts") for Microsoft Entra ID?
column3: Yes, and at least one is excluded from MFA and Conditional Access polices and has an Microsoft Entra PIM permanent role assignment of Global Admin to Microsoft Entra ID

column2: Which option describes your current monitoring, logging, and alerting implementation for authentication, authorization and activity in Microsoft Entra ID and Azure Subscriptions?
column3: No monitoring, logging or alerting.

column2: Which option describes your current monitoring, logging, and alerting implementation for authentication, authorization and activity in Microsoft Entra ID and Azure Subscriptions?
column3: All Microsoft Entra audit & sign-in logs are sent to a central Log Analytics workspace, but no alerting is configured.
column4: All Microsoft Entra audit & sign-in logs are sent to a central Log Analytics workspace, but no alerting is configured.

column2: Which option describes your current monitoring, logging, and alerting implementation for authentication, authorization and activity in Microsoft Entra ID and Azure Subscriptions?
column3: All Microsoft Entra audit & sign-in logs + all Azure Subscription Activity logs are sent to a central Log Analytics workspace, but no alerting is configured.

column2: Which option describes your current monitoring, logging, and alerting implementation for authentication, authorization and activity in Microsoft Entra ID and Azure Subscriptions?
column3: All Microsoft Entra audit & sign-in logs are sent to a central Log Analytics workspace. Alerting is configured based on these logs for scenarios like the use of emergency access accounts.

column2: Which option describes your current monitoring, logging, and alerting implementation for authentication, authorization and activity in Microsoft Entra ID and Azure Subscriptions?
column3: All Microsoft Entra audit & sign-in logs + all Azure Subscription Activity logs are sent to a central Log Analytics workspace. Alerting is configured based on these logs for scenarios like the use of emergency access accounts.

column2: Which option describes your current monitoring, logging, and alerting implementation for authentication, authorization and activity in Microsoft Entra ID and Azure Subscriptions?
column3: All Microsoft Entra audit & sign-in logs + all Azure Subscription Activity logs are sent to a central Log Analytics workspace. Alerting is configured based on these logs for scenarios like the use of emergency access accounts, and Microsoft Sentinel provides analysis and alerts.

column2: How do external users, like partners, gain access to manage your Azure resources within your Azure subscriptions?
column3: No access, or access isn't needed.

column2: How do external users, like partners, gain access to manage your Azure resources within your Azure subscriptions?
column3: Microsoft Entra guest users (B2B) are invited into our Microsoft Entra tenant.
column4: Microsoft Entra guest users (B2B) are invited into our Microsoft Entra tenant.

column2: How do external users, like partners, gain access to manage your Azure resources within your Azure subscriptions?
column3: Azure Lighthouse delegation.

column2: How do external users, like partners, gain access to manage your Azure resources within your Azure subscriptions?
column3: A mixture of both Microsoft Entra guest users (B2B) invitation and Azure Lighthouse delegation.

column2: Which of the following practices do you use when you grant access to resources in your Azure environments via Azure RBAC (IAM)?
column3: RBAC assignments are given to individual users.
column4: RBAC assignments are given to individual users.

column2: Which of the following practices do you use when you grant access to resources in your Azure environments via Azure RBAC (IAM)?
column3: RBAC assignments are only given to groups (cloud only or synchronized). Users are added to the groups.

column2: Which of the following practices do you use when you grant access to resources in your Azure environments via Azure RBAC (IAM)?
column3: RBAC assignments are only given to groups (cloud only). Users are added to the groups.

column2: Which of the following practices do you use when you grant access to resources in your Azure environments via Azure RBAC (IAM)?
column3: RBAC assignments are only given to groups (cloud only or synchronized). Users added to groups, and all assignments (except "read only" permissions) are enforced using Microsoft Entra PIM.

column2: Which of the following practices do you use when you define Azure RBAC (IAM) roles to assign to identities?
column3: Only built-in RBAC roles are assigned. These roles grant higher level roles to cover all required permissions, even for actions that may not be required (like assigning Owner or Contributor to everyone)
column4: Only built-in RBAC roles are assigned. These roles grant higher level roles to cover all required permissions, even for actions that may not be required (like assigning Owner or Contributor to everyone)

column2: Which of the following practices do you use when you define Azure RBAC (IAM) roles to assign to identities?
column3: Only built-in RBAC roles are assigned. These roles assign numerous built-in roles multiple times to tightly scope and control permissions and ensure that only required permissions are given.

column2: Which of the following practices do you use when you define Azure RBAC (IAM) roles to assign to identities?
column3: Custom RBAC roles are assigned for all requirements.

column2: Which of the following practices do you use when you define Azure RBAC (IAM) roles to assign to identities?
column3: Custom RBAC role assignments are used alongside built-in role assignments to provide what permissions the built-in roles don't include. Custom RBAC roles are only assigned when absolutely necessary, since custom requirements are not covered by the built-in roles or any combination of built-in roles.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: We do not have a Hub and Spoke topology based on traditional Virtual Networks. We use Azure VWAN instead. (If you select this alternative, skip the following options and move on to the next question).

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: Our organization deployed resources across one or multiple Azure regions. While some traffic across Azure regions is expected (such as traffic between two virtual networks across two different Azure regions), we do not require a full mesh network across all Azure regions.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: We require full control and granularity for manual configuration of our Azure network routing policy.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: We have a low number of remote or branch locations per region (fewer than 100 IPsec Site-to-Site tunnels).

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: We connect our Landing zone Virtual Networks to a Central Hub virtual network through Vnet Peering for cross-premises connectivity via ExpressRoute, VPN for branch connectivity, NVAs and UDRs for spoke-to-spoke connectivity, Azure Firewall or a partner NVA (as required) for internet-outbound protection.
column4: We connect our Landing zone Virtual Networks to a Central Hub virtual network through Vnet Peering for cross-premises connectivity via ExpressRoute, VPN for branch connectivity, NVAs and UDRs for spoke-to-spoke connectivity, Azure Firewall or a partner NVA (as required) for internet-outbound protection.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: When one of the following conditions is true, we use a topology of multiple Hub Virtual networks or even Landing Zones Virtual Networks connected with multiple ExpressRoute circuits: - We need a higher level of isolation. - We need dedicated ExpressRoute bandwidth for specific business units. - We have reached the maximum number of connections per ExpressRoute gateway.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: We use multiprotocol label switching, SD-WAN, and our existing network to connect branch locations with corporate headquarters. We use Azure Route Server when transit between ExpressRoute and VPN gateways is required.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: We have hub-and-spoke networks in multiple Azure regions. When a few of our landing zones need to connect across regions, we use global virtual network peering to directly connect landing zone virtual networks that need to route traffic to each other.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: When our Landing Zone Virtual Networks from different Azure regions need to communicate, we either: - Deploy a partner NVA or Azure Firewall in the Hub, then initiate Global Vnet peering between the hubs. - Interconnect ExpressRoute Gateways and Circuits across regions. In this scenario, both gateways are connected to both circuits, with different weights in the connection resource.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: We deploy each region's hub network resources into separate resource groups and sort them into each deployed region.

column2: Our organization created a Hub and Spoke topology using Virtual Networks, and the following statements are true about our requirements/environment
column3: We use Azure Monitor for Networks to monitor our virtual networks' end-to-end state.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We do not have a Hub and Spoke topology based on Azure VWAN. We use traditional Virtual Networks instead. (If you select this alternative, skip the following options and move on to the next question).
column4: We do not have a Hub and Spoke topology based on Azure VWAN. We use traditional Virtual Networks instead. (If you select this alternative, skip the following options and move on to the next question).

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: At least one of the following statements is true about our requirements/environment: - Our organization has resources deployed across several Azure regions and. We have global connectivity between VNets in these Azure regions and between multiple on-premises locations through the Azure Global Network. - Our organization intends to integrate a large-scale branch network that requires more than 100 branch sites for native IPsec termination directly into Azure using a software-defined WAN (SD-WAN) deployment. - Our organization requires transitive routing between VPN and ExpressRoute. Remote branches linked via site-to-site VPN and/or remote users linked via point-to-site VPN connect to on-premises datacenters via Azure using the ExpressRoute private infrastructure. - Our organization needs an aggregated throughput higher than 10 Gbps between Azure and on-premises locations.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We connect multiple landing zones together across Azure regions using a Virtual WAN hub for each Azure region and a common global Azure Virtual WAN.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We deploy all Virtual WAN resources into a single resource group in our connectivity subscription, even when we deploy across multiple regions.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We use virtual hub routing features to further segment traffic between VNets and branches.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We use ExpressRoute to connect Virtual WAN hubs to on-premises datacenters.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We deploy required shared services, like DNS servers, in a dedicated spoke virtual network.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We connect branches and remote locations to the nearest Virtual WAN hub using Site-to-Site VPN, or we enable branch connectivity to Virtual WAN via an SD-WAN partner solution.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: When required, we connect users to our Virtual WAN hub via a Point-to-Site VPN.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We follow the principle of "traffic in Azure stays in Azure" so that communication across resources in Azure occurs via the Microsoft backbone network, even when the resources are in different regions.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We house the Azure Virtual WAN and Azure Firewall resources within our connectivity subscription.

column2: Our organization created a Global Network using Azure VWAN, and the following statements are true about our requirements/deployment
column3: We have a single Azure DDoS standard protection plan deployed in our connectivity subscription.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure are true
column3: We require private connectivity to Azure, and we currently use VPN.
column4: We require private connectivity to Azure, and we currently use VPN.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure are true
column3: We require private connectivity to Azure, and we currently use ExpressRoute circuits.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure are true
column3: We require encryption and private connectivity for Azure, and we currently use ExpressRoute Direct with MacSec enabled between our routes and Microsoft Edge routers.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure are true
column3: We use ExpressRoute circuit with private peering configured, and we enabled FastPath when we created the ExpressRoute connection.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure are true
column3: We have an on-premises datacenter that's connected to two ExpressRoute peering locations to increase overall reliability.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure are true
column3: When an Azure region supports availability zones, we deploy only ExpressRoute gateways that support zonal deployment, like VpnGw[x]AZ sku.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure are true
column3: Our on-premises datacenter connects to one or more Hub Virtual Networks/Virtual WAN hubs in a particular Azure region. The total combined bandwidth requires no more than 10Gbps throughput, and we use ExpressRoute through a service provider. When more than 10Gbps is needed, we use ExpressRoute Direct circuits.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure are true
column3: We use ExpressRoute network insights to monitor our ExpressRoute components (peerings, connections, and gateways).

column2: The following statements about our strategy for assigning IP addresses to Azure, on-premises, and other cloud providers are true
column3: We use only private IP address ranges from RFC 1918 for our private On-premises networks and/or Azure Virtual Networks.
column4: We use only private IP address ranges from RFC 1918 for our private On-premises networks and/or Azure Virtual Networks.

column2: The following statements about our strategy for assigning IP addresses to Azure, on-premises, and other cloud providers are true
column3: We do not use any of the following IP address ranges as Address Space of our Azure or On-Premises networks: 224.0.0.0/4 (multicast), 255.255.255.255/32 (broadcast), 127.0.0.0/8 (loopback), 169.254.0.0/16 (link-local), and  168.63.129.16/32 (internal DNS).
column4: We do not use any of the following IP address ranges as Address Space of our Azure or On-Premises networks: 224.0.0.0/4 (multicast), 255.255.255.255/32 (broadcast), 127.0.0.0/8 (loopback), 169.254.0.0/16 (link-local), and  168.63.129.16/32 (internal DNS).

column2: The following statements about our strategy for assigning IP addresses to Azure, on-premises, and other cloud providers are true
column3: We do not create large Azure Virtual Networks like (/16), unless for Landing Zone Virtual Networks hosting services that may require thousands of IP Addresses, such as Azure Kubernetes or Azure Databricks.

column2: The following statements about our strategy for assigning IP addresses to Azure, on-premises, and other cloud providers are true
column3: We use an IP address management solution that helps us to reserve and assign IP addresses ranges and ensure admins don't create networks with IP overlap.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure PaaS services are true
column3: We use virtual network injection for supported Azure services to make them available from within your virtual network, and we are locking down the communication within the virtual network by using UDRs and NSGs.
column4: We use virtual network injection for supported Azure services to make them available from within your virtual network, and we are locking down the communication within the virtual network by using UDRs and NSGs.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure PaaS services are true
column3: When available we always use Private Link Endpoints for Azure PaaS services that do not require public access.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure PaaS services are true
column3: When virtual network injection or Private Link Endpoints are not available, we use ExpressRoute with Microsoft peering, and we have restricted the Networks that can reach out to the services separately, in the Firewall setting of each service.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure PaaS services are true
column3: When Virtual Network Injection or Private Link Endpoints are not available, we use Service Endpoints. We only enable them on the subnets that really need access to a particular Azure PaaS service, and we only use them when there are no data exfiltration concerns.

column2: The following statements about our connectivity to Azure PaaS services are true
column3: Our corporate security policy requires that we limit Cross-Tenant Private Link Endpoint connections in Azure, and in order to achieve that we have implemented Azure Policies to meet that requirement.

column2: The following statements are true about how we secure our workloads from inbound HTTP/S connectivity from the internet
column3: We use Application Gateway v2 for secure delivery of HTTP/S applications and ensure that WAF protection and policies are enabled.

column2: The following statements are true about how we secure our workloads from inbound HTTP/S connectivity from the internet
column3: (Single region) We use Application Gateway v2 (or a partner NVA) and ensure that WAF protection and policies are enabled for secure delivery of external-facing HTTP/S applications, and we deploy them within the landing-zone virtual network and with the applications that they're securing.

column2: The following statements are true about how we secure our workloads from inbound HTTP/S connectivity from the internet
column3: (Multi-region) When using Azure Front Door and Application Gateway v2 to protect HTTP/S applications, we use WAF policies in Front Door and lock Application Gateway down to only receive traffic from Front Door.

column2: The following statements are true about how we secure our workloads from inbound HTTP/S connectivity from the internet
column3: We have no public facing application.
column4: We have no public facing application.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for "Outbound Internet" access
column3: We do not use Azure's default internet outbound (SNAT) for any scenario. We use Azure Firewall or a partner NVA to govern Azure outbound traffic to the internet.
column4: We do not use Azure's default internet outbound (SNAT) for any scenario. We use Azure Firewall or a partner NVA to govern Azure outbound traffic to the internet.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for "Outbound Internet" access
column3: We use NAT gateway for Online Landing Zones Vnets not connected to the Hub VNet, where compute resources require internet outbound access and do not need any of the security features provided by Azure Firewall or a third-party NVA.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for our inbound and outbound internet connectivity
column3: We prevent exposure of VM management ports to the internet by using Azure Policy to prevent VM creation with a public IP attached.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for our inbound and outbound internet connectivity
column3: We use Azure Bastion to access jump-box virtual machines for management purposes.
column4: We use Azure Bastion to access jump-box virtual machines for management purposes.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for our inbound and outbound internet connectivity
column3: We use Azure DDoS Protection Standard protection plans to help protect all Virtual Networks hosting any resource with a Public IP.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for our inbound and outbound internet connectivity
column3: We do not replicate on-premises perimeter network concepts and architectures into Azure. Similar security capabilities are available in Azure, but the implementation and architecture must be adapted to the cloud.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy of how we implement NSG to protect traffic across subnets, as well as east-west traffic across the platform
column3: We use NSGs to help protect traffic across subnets, as well as east/west traffic across the platform (traffic between landing zones).
column4: We use NSGs to help protect traffic across subnets, as well as east/west traffic across the platform (traffic between landing zones).

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy of how we implement NSG to protect traffic across subnets, as well as east-west traffic across the platform
column3: Application teams use application security groups at the subnet-level to help protect multitier VMs within landing zones.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy of how we implement NSG to protect traffic across subnets, as well as east-west traffic across the platform
column3: We use NSGs and Application Security Groups to micro-segment traffic within the landing zone and avoid using a central NVA to filter traffic flows.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy of how we implement NSG to protect traffic across subnets, as well as east-west traffic across the platform
column3: We enable NSG flow logs on all critical VNets/subnets in our subscription as an audit-ability and security best practice.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for Traffic Inspection
column3: We use Azure Firewall Premium or a partner NVA if advanced firewall capabilities are required (TLS inspection, network intrusion detection and prevention system (IDPS), URL filtering, web categories), for all inbound connections and for East/west traffic filtering (when required).

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for Traffic Inspection
column3: When we use Azure Firewall we use Azure Firewall Manager to deploy and manage Azure firewalls across Virtual WAN hubs or in hub virtual networks. When we use partner NVAs, we leverage similar capabilities provided by the vendor of the partner NVA, to deploy, configure and manage them at scale.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for Traffic Inspection
column3: We have a Global Azure Firewall Policy to govern security posture across the global network environment, and we also use some more granular Azure Firewall policies to meet the requirements of specific regions by delegating incremental firewall policies to local security teams via Azure role-based access control. When using partner NVAs we use similar capabilities provided by the vendor of the partner NVA, to deploy, configure and manage firewall policies at scale.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for Traffic Inspection
column3: When we use partner NVAs for East/West and/or North/South traffic protection and filtering, for Virtual WAN network topologies we deploy the partner NVAs to a separate virtual network (for example, NVA Vnet), and then we connect it to the regional Virtual WAN hub and to the landing zones that require access to NVAs; and for non-Virtual WAN network topologies (Traditional Virtual Networks), we deploy the partner NVAs in the Hub virtual network.
column4: When we use partner NVAs for East/West and/or North/South traffic protection and filtering, for Virtual WAN network topologies we deploy the partner NVAs to a separate virtual network (for example, NVA Vnet), and then we connect it to the regional Virtual WAN hub and to the landing zones that require access to NVAs; and for non-Virtual WAN network topologies (Traditional Virtual Networks), we deploy the partner NVAs in the Hub virtual network.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for Traffic Inspection
column3: Use Network Watcher packets to capture despite the limited capture window.

column2: The following statements are true about our requirements and strategy for Traffic Inspection
column3: Use partner solutions for scenarios that require deep packet inspection.

column2: The following statements about our central DNS name resolution implementation are true
column3: We have a delegated zone for name resolution (such as azure.contoso.com)

column2: The following statements about our central DNS name resolution implementation are true
column3: We automatically manage the lifecycle of DNS records for virtual machines deployed in a virtual network by enabling auto-registration for Azure Private DNS.

column2: The following statements about our central DNS name resolution implementation are true
column3: When an environment requires name resolution across on-premises and Azure, we use existing DNS infrastructure (like Active Directory integrated DNS) deployed on at least two VMs. We configure our virtual network DNS settings to use those DNS servers.
column4: When an environment requires name resolution across on-premises and Azure, we use existing DNS infrastructure (like Active Directory integrated DNS) deployed on at least two VMs. We configure our virtual network DNS settings to use those DNS servers.

column2: The following statements about our central DNS name resolution implementation are true
column3: We use Azure Firewall with DNS proxy or a Virtual Machine as a resolver for cross-premises DNS resolution with Azure Private DNS.

column2: The following statements about our central DNS name resolution implementation are true
column3: We link Azure Private DNS zones to virtual networks, and we use DNS servers as hybrid resolvers with conditional forwarding to on-premises DNS names (for example, corporate.contoso.com). We configure on-premises servers with conditional forwarders to resolver VMs in Azure for our Azure Private DNS zone (for example, azure.contoso.com).

column2: The following statements about our central DNS name resolution implementation are true
column3: We create Azure Private DNS zones within a global connectivity subscription. The zones we create include zones required for accessing Azure PaaS services via a private endpoint (for example, privatelink.database.windows.net, or privatelink.blob.core.windows.net).

column2: Which option best describes your current usage of Management Groups?
column3: No usage of management groups, or use of the Tenant Root Management Group only.
column4: No usage of management groups, or use of the Tenant Root Management Group only.

column2: Which option best describes your current usage of Management Groups?
column3: A single management group on top of the Tenant Root Management Group

column2: Which option best describes your current usage of Management Groups?
column3: Management groups reflect organizational hierarchy and departments. The management groups contain associated subscriptions for each department.

column2: Which option best describes your current usage of Management Groups?
column3: Management groups reflect applications/services and their various environments (e.g. prod, test, dev).

column2: Which option best describes your current usage of Management Groups?
column3: Management groups reflect archetypes built using Azure Policy & RBAC assignments to define different workload requirements. An example of this is the Azure Landing Zone conceptual architecture management group hierarchy.

column2: Which option best describes your current usage of Management Groups?
column3: Management Groups reflect archetypes and a "canary" testing hierarchy is in use.

column2: Which of these options best describes your current usage of Subscriptions and how you democratize their usage?
column3: No democratization. One subscription for all resources hosted in Azure.

column2: Which of these options best describes your current usage of Subscriptions and how you democratize their usage?
column3: Two subscriptions, one for platform shared services and another for applications/workloads.
column4: Two subscriptions, one for platform shared services and another for applications/workloads.

column2: Which of these options best describes your current usage of Subscriptions and how you democratize their usage?
column3: Separate subscriptions for different environments (e.g. prod, test, dev). The subscriptions are shared by all applications/workloads and their teams.

column2: Which of these options best describes your current usage of Subscriptions and how you democratize their usage?
column3: Separate subscriptions for each application/workload team. Each team can have multiple subscriptions depending on their particular application/workload requirements.

column2: Which of these options best describes your current usage of Subscriptions and how you democratize their usage?
column3: Separate subscriptions for each application/workload team. Each team can have multiple subscriptions depending on their particular application/workload requirements. There are also separate subscriptions for central shared platform services.

column2: How do you currently create/provision subscriptions within your environment?
column3: Manually, by clicking "Add Subscription" in the Azure Portal or EA portal.

column2: How do you currently create/provision subscriptions within your environment?
column3: Manually, by raising a ticket with our partner/CSP to create one.
column4: Manually, by raising a ticket with our partner/CSP to create one.

column2: How do you currently create/provision subscriptions within your environment?
column3: Manually, via an API call (ARM, REST, Bicep, Terraform, etc.), from a manual request (e-mail, ticket from ITSM tool).

column2: How do you currently create/provision subscriptions within your environment?
column3: Automatically, via an API call (ARM, REST, Bicep, Terraform, etc.) triggered through a pipeline/integration tool.

column2: How do you track costs for Azure resources?
column3: We don't track costs for Azure.
column4: We don't track costs for Azure.

column2: How do you track costs for Azure resources?
column3: We track costs at the subscription level.

column2: How do you track costs for Azure resources?
column3: We track costs for some individual workloads.

column2: How do you track costs for Azure resources?
column3: We use a cost management tool to track costs for all workloads.

column2: How do you track costs for Azure resources?
column3: Workload owners use a cost management tool to track their resource costs, and they are responsible for optimizing their spending.

column2: How do you use Azure resource tagging within your environment?
column3: We don't tag Azure resources with metadata.

column2: How do you use Azure resource tagging within your environment?
column3: Azure resource tagging is ad-hoc and manual.
column4: Azure resource tagging is ad-hoc and manual.

column2: How do you use Azure resource tagging within your environment?
column3: Some Azure resources must have a defined set of tags and are audited for compliance.

column2: How do you use Azure resource tagging within your environment?
column3: All azure resources must have a defined set of tags and are audited for compliance.

column2: How do you use Azure resource tagging within your environment?
column3: All Azure resources must have a defined set of tags, and we enforce compliance via automation and/or policy.

column2: How do you ensure you're optimizing your spending on Azure services?
column3: We don't actively review resource utilization for cost optimization opportunities.
column4: We don't actively review resource utilization for cost optimization opportunities.

column2: How do you ensure you're optimizing your spending on Azure services?
column3: Some teams review Azure Advisor for recommendations when workload costs exceed expectations.

column2: How do you ensure you're optimizing your spending on Azure services?
column3: Some teams proactively review Azure Advisor (or a similar tool) recommendations for cost optimization opportunities.

column2: How do you ensure you're optimizing your spending on Azure services?
column3: Teams proactively review Azure Advisor (or similar tool) recommendations for cost optimization opportunities.

column2: How do you ensure you're optimizing your spending on Azure services?
column3: Teams proactively review Azure Advisor (or similar tool) recommendations for cost optimization opportunities and also leverage Reserved Instances.

column2: How do you retain logs for insights and analytics?
column3: We don't retain logs from Azure services.

column2: How do you retain logs for insights and analytics?
column3: Log retention is ad-hoc and configured manually.
column4: Log retention is ad-hoc and configured manually.

column2: How do you retain logs for insights and analytics?
column3: Log retention is automated for some resources and manual for others.

column2: How do you retain logs for insights and analytics?
column3: Log retention is enforced, and Azure logs are sent to an on-premises system.

column2: How do you retain logs for insights and analytics?
column3: Log retention is enforced, and Azure logs are stored in Azure.

column2: How do you ensure Azure resource configurations are compliant with organizational and regulatory standards?
column3: We have no mechanism in place to evaluate Azure resource configurations and ensure compliance.
column4: We have no mechanism in place to evaluate Azure resource configurations and ensure compliance.

column2: How do you ensure Azure resource configurations are compliant with organizational and regulatory standards?
column3: Azure resource configuration evaluation for compliance is a manual process.

column2: How do you ensure Azure resource configurations are compliant with organizational and regulatory standards?
column3: Some Azure resource configurations are automatically audited against documented standards.

column2: How do you ensure Azure resource configurations are compliant with organizational and regulatory standards?
column3: All Azure resource configurations are automatically audited against documented standards. Remediation activities are done manually.

column2: How do you ensure Azure resource configurations are compliant with organizational and regulatory standards?
column3: All Azure resource configurations are automatically audited against documented standards. Remediation activities are automated, and/or non-compliant resource deployments are blocked.

column2: How do you meet your security requirements in Azure?
column3: We haven't defined or documented security requirements for Azure.

column2: How do you meet your security requirements in Azure?
column3: Some Azure resources are integrated with our security assessment and SIEM solutions.
column4: Some Azure resources are integrated with our security assessment and SIEM solutions.

column2: How do you meet your security requirements in Azure?
column3: Some Azure subscriptions and resources are integrated with our security assessment and SIEM solutions. Secure resource configurations are defined, but not enforced.

column2: How do you meet your security requirements in Azure?
column3: All Azure subscriptions and resources are manually integrated with our security assessment and SIEM solutions. Secure resource configurations are defined, but not enforced.

column2: How do you meet your security requirements in Azure?
column3: All Azure subscriptions and resources are automatically integrated at time of deployment with our security assessment and SIEM solutions. Secure resource configurations are defined and enforced.

column2: How do you determine whether to allow Azure services in your environment or not?
column3: We have no defined process for evaluating Azure resource types before allowing them in our environment.
column4: We have no defined process for evaluating Azure resource types before allowing them in our environment.

column2: How do you determine whether to allow Azure services in your environment or not?
column3: We assess the security configurations of some Azure services in our environment.

column2: How do you determine whether to allow Azure services in your environment or not?
column3: We assess the security configurations of most Azure services in our environment.

column2: How do you determine whether to allow Azure services in your environment or not?
column3: We have a well-defined process for assessing Azure service security configurations as well as monitoring, alerting, and integrating services with existing systems. Secure resource configurations are defined but not enforced.

column2: How do you determine whether to allow Azure services in your environment or not?
column3: We have a well-defined process for assessing Azure service security configurations as well as monitoring, alerting, and integrating services with existing systems. Secure resource configurations are defined and automatically enforced.

column2: How do you manage and deploy changes to your Azure Landing Zone environment(s)?
column3: Manually, through the Azure Portal.
column4: Manually, through the Azure Portal.

column2: How do you manage and deploy changes to your Azure Landing Zone environment(s)?
column3: Manually, through imperative tools like Azure PowerShell or Azure CLI.

column2: How do you manage and deploy changes to your Azure Landing Zone environment(s)?
column3: Manually, via declarative Infrastructure-as-Code tools like ARM Template, Bicep, Terraform, etc.

column2: How do you manage and deploy changes to your Azure Landing Zone environment(s)?
column3: Automatically, through a CI/CD pipeline, using imperative tools like Azure PowerShell or Azure CLI. Code is stored centrally in a Git repository.

column2: How do you manage and deploy changes to your Azure Landing Zone environment(s)?
column3: Automatically, through a CI/CD pipeline, using Infrastructure-as-Code tools like ARM Template, Bicep, Terraform, etc. Code is stored centrally in a Git repository.

column2: How do different teams work together and deploy and manage their Azure resource deployments?
column3: Teams use a common CI/CD pipeline (or multiple CI/CD pipelines) and Git repository to deploy to Azure.

column2: How do different teams work together and deploy and manage their Azure resource deployments?
column3: All teams are encouraged to deploy resources in whatever way fits their requirements for achieving their goals and SLAs whilst using declarative Infrastructure-as-Code tooling. Teams work separately from each other in their own Git repository and CI/CD pipeline (or pipelines), which gives each team autonomy.
column4: All teams are encouraged to deploy resources in whatever way fits their requirements for achieving their goals and SLAs whilst using declarative Infrastructure-as-Code tooling. Teams work separately from each other in their own Git repository and CI/CD pipeline (or pipelines), which gives each team autonomy.

column2: Which Azure Policy effect(s) do you use in your Azure Landing Zones environment to control and audit subscriptions and their resources?
column3: Deny, Disabled
column4: Deny, Disabled

column2: Which Azure Policy effect(s) do you use in your Azure Landing Zones environment to control and audit subscriptions and their resources?
column3: Append, Modify, DeployIfNotExists

column2: Which Azure Policy effect(s) do you use in your Azure Landing Zones environment to control and audit subscriptions and their resources?
column3: Audit, AuditIfNotExists, and/or setting "Enforcement Mode" on Policy Assignments to "Disabled" (which achieves same result as the Audit effect for Modify & DeployIfNotExists).

column2: How do your structure you teams internally, and how do they interact to deploy and manage Azure?
column3: We don't have team structures defined. Everyone has the same access and can deploy whatever they need, wherever they need.

column2: How do your structure you teams internally, and how do they interact to deploy and manage Azure?
column3: A single central IT team deploys and manages everything in Azure, platform, and applications.
column4: A single central IT team deploys and manages everything in Azure, platform, and applications.

column2: How do your structure you teams internally, and how do they interact to deploy and manage Azure?
column3: A platform team (or teams) deploys and manages platform resources like Management Groups, Policy, RBAC, Hub Networking & Hybrid Connectivity (like VPN/ExpressRoute), Identity, etc. Platform functions might be split further between teams, such as networking resources being managed by a networking team and additional teams being in charge of identity and Azure platform/governance resources.
